citations.narrative:
A portion of the perimeter fence failed to meet the minimum height requirement, without written approval by the
Administrator. The facility has two large felines kept in outdoor housing facilities and is required to maintain a perimeter
fence at least 8 feet in height. The southern section of the perimeter fence is made up of wooden boards approximately 7
feet in height. This fence is capped with a framed wooden lattice approximately 18 inches tall. The facility is closed to the
public during the winter season and will not open back up until April this year. They use this time to make repairs and
renovations. Behind the enclosure housing four muntjacs, a portion of the lattice cap, approximately 20 feet in length, was
removed so that trees outside the perimeter fence could be trimmed back. At the time of inspection, the facility was not
actively working in that area, and the cap was not attached to the fence. As a result, that portion of the perimeter fence
failed to meet the 8-foot requirement.
An improper perimeter fence can provide unwanted animals and unauthorized people an opportunity to gain access to the
animals behind it.
All outdoor housing facilities must be enclosed by a perimeter fence that is of sufficient height to keep animals and
unauthorized persons out. Fences less than 8 feet high for potentially dangerous animals such as large felines (tigers,
cougars, etc.) must be approved in writing by the Administrator. To be corrected by March 25, 2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
3.127(d) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
A portion of the perimeter fence failed to meet the minimum height requirement, without written approval by the 
Administrator. The facility has two large felines kept in outdoor housing facilities and is required to maintain a perimeter 
fence at least 8 feet in height. The southern section of the perimeter fence is made up of wooden boards approximately 7 
feet in height. This fence is capped with a framed wooden lattice approximately 18 inches tall. The facility is closed to the 
public during the winter season and will not open back up until April this year. They use this time to make repairs and 
renovations. Behind the enclosure housing four muntjacs, a portion of the lattice cap, approximately 20 feet in length, was 
removed so that trees outside the perimeter fence could be trimmed back. At the time of inspection, the facility was not 
actively working in that area, and the cap was not attached to the fence. As a result, that portion of the perimeter fence 
failed to meet the 8-foot requirement. 
 
An improper perimeter fence can provide unwanted animals and unauthorized people an opportunity to gain access to the 
animals behind it. 
 
All outdoor housing facilities must be enclosed by a perimeter fence that is of sufficient height to keep animals and 
unauthorized persons out. Fences less than 8 feet high for potentially dangerous animals such as large felines (tigers, 
cougars, etc.) must be approved in writing by the Administrator. To be corrected by March 25, 2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
